content.webTitle: Louis van Gaal hopes Wayne Rooney can end goal drought at Everton

fields.headline: Louis van Gaal hopes Wayne Rooney can end goal drought at Everton
fields.bodyText: Louis van Gaal wants Wayne Rooney’s disappointing goal return at Everton to change, with the Manchester United captain having scored only twice in nine Premier League appearances at Goodison Park. United are at Everton on Saturday and Rooney is available again after the ankle knock that ruled him out of England’s Euro 2016 qualifiers during the international break. Rooney has not scored at Goodison Park since April 2007, has only one goal in the Premier League this season, and has not registered away in the competition for 11 months. Asked about the 29-year-old’s barren run away in the league, Van Gaal said: “So maybe against Everton he can change but his average is not so good [against them]. So it’s getting time that he changed that pattern. I don’t know [why]. That you have to ask Wayne but I’m a manager who analyses opponents and gives him advice as to how we can disorganise Everton’s defence and then maybe he can score. “That is what I’m doing, not only for Wayne but all the players, especially from the view of the team tactics rather than the individual tactics.” Rooney has also failed to create a single goal for the side in the league this term. Yet Van Gaal refused to state the striker is out of form. “You cannot answer that because he’s part of the team,” the Dutchman said. “He’s scored for us in the Champions League. So for me it is not so important who is scoring. We have scored a lot of goals. In the beginning your criticism was we don’t score goals but now we’ve scored a lot of goals and you’re picking up an individual player and I don’t like that.” Van Gaal maintains that Rooney is still his most vital player. “He’s our captain so that’s very important because his influence is bigger than every other player in our group. He’s a very important player for me, his colleagues, everybody,” said the 63-year-old, who does not believe Rooney is burdened by being the captain. “I don’t believe it with his personality.” Van Gaal believes the side are making enough opportunities for the Liverpudlian to score. “Have we created enough chances?” he asked. “Yes, I think so. I think we have chances to score in every game. Also against Arsenal, after the first 20 minutes we have created a lot of chances. And also after [going behind] 3-0. So I think the spirit in the team is very good. It’s not a given in every team that you can create a lot of chances at 3-0 down and we did it, so that’s the positive thing. But of course it’s very important that out of your chances you score and against Arsenal we didn’t.” Anthony Martial was voted the Premier League player of the month for September after an impressive start to his United career. The 19-year-old is playing at centre-forward where Van Gaal had planned for Rooney to play this season. Asked why the manager had changed this strategy Van Gaal said: “He’s second striker. Our 10 is a second striker. That’s what my preference is but sometimes I need another type in midfield. We’ll have to see if he continues with that because Wayne can play in different positions.” Bastian Schweinsteiger is available again after a minor thigh problem. “It’s the same thing as with Rooney. I was happy that my colleagues [England and Germany coaches] didn’t take risks with them because Bastian could maybe have played the second match but he didn’t take that risk so that’s good for me,” said Van Gaal. Everton may be the subject of a buyout from a group associated with the Major League Soccer franchise Sporting Kansas City, according to reports.
